awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Coupling and Cohesion as Factors Affecting Vulnerability to Abrupt Climate Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Benjamin Vining, of the University of Arkansas-Fayetteville, along with collaborators from the University of Louisiana-Lafayette, the University of Florida-Gainesville, and in Peru, will examine how the organization of different agricultural production systems relates to climate change vulnerabilities.  Climate change is increasingly a public and policy concern. This research will focus on understanding how different agricultural strategies were used as el Nino disasters occurred in the past with changing frequency and strength.  Understanding how agriculturalists switched between productive strategies will improve long-term adaptations to climate change, provide theoretical and applied models for how to address climate change in future planning and development, and promote local adaptive capacities.  Using agriculture as a set of case studies, these models can be generalized to other forms of economic networks to understand how various strategies can promote resilience. This project will establish new multidisciplinary approaches to tackle such complex problems as climate change adaptation, and train graduate students from the partner institutions and countries in international collaborations. 
 
Dr. Vining and his team will examine how prehispanic agriculturalists developed and switched between various productive strategies as the el Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) changed in frequency and severity.  The study region, north coastal Peru, hosted a series of civilizations between approximately 2000 BC - 1450 AD, including the Moche, Lambayeque, and Chimu societies.  However, the region is also particularly vulnerable to el Nino induced disasters, such as occurred recently in 2016-2017.  Initial archaeological work in this region indicates that prehispanic agriculture was based on a suite of strategies.  The complex economies that supported prehispanic societies were based on in part on switching amongst agricultural strategies as climatic contexts shifted.  The researchers come from the fields of archaeology, paleolimnology and palaeoclimate, and ecological modeling. A principal objective will be to combine high-precision dating of agricultural systems with paleoclimate conditions reconstructed from lake cores.  The researchers will use this multidisplinary methodological background to improve historic reconstructions of past ENSO variations, record archaeological examples of agricultural technologies in their environmental context, and reconstruct how different strategies were employed as ENSO effected climate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This interdisciplinary project aimed to understand how different agricultural strategies related to climate change vulnerabilities, using the Chicama Valley of coastal northern Peru as a case study. A principal objective was to combine high-precision dating of agricultural systems with paleoclimate conditions reconstructed from lake cores (paleolimnology). For the paleolimnological aspect of the project, we analyzed sediment core sequences from Lagunas Sausacocha and Huaylillas, located in the upper Chicama Valley.

The sediment core sequence from Sausacocha is divided into three units: 1) from 11,300 to 8,800 years before present (BP), a period of low water levels characterized by high inorganic sediment input, 2) from 8,800 to 3,400 years BP, higher and mostly stable lake levels with abundant accumulation of organic matter, and 3) from 3,400 years BP to present, several alternating sequences of organic and inorganic sediments. Most interestingly, although other paleoclimate records suggest increased aridity during unit 2, this is not obviously recorded in Sausacocha. Either the lake was deep and large enough to sustain an adequate volume or evaporative water loss was minimized due to local topography. We interpret unit 3 to reflect increased catchment erosion or riverine sediment flux. It is unclear whether these inorganic sediment pulses were initiated by human activity within the catchment or climatically driven landscape change or a combination of both.

Similar to Sausacocha, the sediment core sequence from Huaylillas can be characterized by the alternation of high inorganic/low organic and high organic/low inorganic sediment. We identified five of these high inorganic/low organic sediment packages in Huaylillas over the last 20,000 years. We interpret the first of these packages (unit I) to be reflective of the local last glacial maximum. Units II-IV reflect erosion of previously glaciated sediment and soil throughout the Holocene, likely climatically driven by periods of increased precipitation. Unit V, dated to around 3,100 years BP, is slightly different with goethite as the primary magnetic mineral and higher organic matter. Unit V may be linked to an increase in El Nino Southern Oscillation events and/or anthropogenic drivers, such as land clearance, mining, or agriculture.

Ongoing work will link these records of climate and human activity to settlement strategies down valley and provide a framework to better understand the social dimensions of vulnerability to abrupt climatic events such as decadal-long shifts in moisture availability and El Nino Southern Oscillation trends.

Through the lifetime of this project, three undergraduate students, all members of under-represented groups in STEM, gained research experience. Students developed skills in laboratory, environmental, and quantitative analysis methods in trans-disciplinary natural science and social-science research.
